Australia: Operation Hurricane: First nuclear test conducted in Australian territory by the United Kingdom off the coast of Western Australia.
Bangladesh: Bengali Language Movement reaches its peak as the police open fire on protesting students.
Belgium: Treaty of Paris establishing the European Coal and Steel Community comes into force.
Bhutan: King Jigme Wangchuck dies; his son Jigme Dorji Wangchuck begins to reign. Bhutan begins a program of planned development and democratization. The same year, the National Assembly is established, and the post of Chief Minister (Gongzim) is abolished.
Brazil: Anchieta rail disaster: A crowded steam-powered passenger train derails while crossing a bridge over the Pavuna River near Anchieta station, sending two old wooden carriages broadside onto the adjacent line. A modern high-speed electric freight train travelling in the opposite direction ploughs into the wooden carriages, telescoping them upwards. The severity of the accident was compounded by the fact that the suburban train is overloaded, with passengers clinging to the sides, underneath and between the carriages. A witness says they saw "passengers flying in all directions when the crash occurred". 119 people are killed and the resulting outcry prompts major new investment in Brazilian railways. Pan Am Flight 202 crashes in the Amazon Basin approximately 220 nautical miles (410 km) southwest of Carolina, Brazil. All 50 people on board are killed in the worst-ever accident involving the Boeing 377. 1952 Transportes Aéreos Nacional Douglas C-47 mid-air explosion: A Douglas C-47A registered PP-ANH is destroyed after an in-flight fire causes it to crash near Palmeiras de Goiás. All 24 people on board are killed. Bob's, Brazil's first fast food chain, opens in Rio de Janeiro.
Chile: Carlos Ibáñez del Campo returns to the presidency, this time via the ballot box, ending the era of the Radical Party.
Cuba: Former president Batista, supported by the army, seizes power once more.
Germany:
East Germany strengthened its border protection regime along the Inner German border.
The General Treaty, which granted West Germany the "authority of a sovereign state", was signed by West Germany, France, the United States and the United Kingdom.
Indinesia:
Amid bitter disputes over the signing of a Mutual Security Agreement with the US, the Sukiman cabinet resigns.
The new cabinet, led by Prime Minister Wilopo is inaugurated.
Army-organized demonstrations take place in Jakarta to demand the dissolution of the legislature. Tank guns and machine guns are trained on the presidential palace. This leads to the suspension of General Nasution as army chief of staff following army indiscipline over command and support that threatens the government.
Italy: Italy becomes a founding member of the European Coal and Steel Community.
Nepal: King Tribhuvan Bir Bikram Shah Dev ascends throne
Philippine: National Press Club established Armed Forces launches Operation Four Roses in Nueva Ecija in the search for Huk strongholds in Sierra Madre mountains. Old Zamboanga is divided into the new provinces of Zamboanga del Norte and Zamboanga del Sur. (Republic Act No. 711) Land-tenure specialist Robert Hardie releases his report regarding the country's problem on tenancy, recommending its abolition.
Poland:
Adoption of Constitution of the People's Republic of Poland
First Legislative election by the one-party rule
Russia: Prague Trials: A series of show trials purged the Czech Communist Party of Jews and insufficiently orthodox Stalinists.
Singapore:
Wilfred Lawson Blythe was appointed as the Acting Governor of the Singapore.
Sir John Fearns Nicoll was appointed as the Governor of the Singapore.
